Get the list of country codes for the "World" region country_codes = wb.region.members('WLD') # Download data for countries only in 2022 df = wb.data.DataFrame(indicators.values(), economy=country_codes, time=2022, skipBlanks=True, labels=True).reset_index() # Delete the 'economy' column df = df.drop(columns=['economy'], errors='ignore') # Create a reversed dictionary mapping indicator codes to names # Rename the columns and convert all names to lowercase df.rename(columns=lambda x: {v: k for k, v in indicators.items()}.get(x, x).lower(), inplace=True) # Sort 'country' in ascending order df = df.sort_values('country', ascending=True) # Reset the index after sorting df = df.reset_index(drop=True) # Display the number of rows and columns print(df.shape) # Display the first few rows of the data print(df.head(3)) # Save the data to a CSV file df.to_csv('wdi.csv', index=False) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (217, 14) country inflation_rate exports_gdp_share gdp_growth_rate \ 0 Afghanistan 13.712102 18.380042 -6.240172 1 Albania 6.725203 37.197082 4.826696 2 Algeria 9.265516 30.808979 3.600000 gdp_per_capita adult_literacy_rate primary_school_enrolment_rate \ 0 357.261153 NaN NaN 1 6846.426694 NaN 96.371230 2 4961.552577 NaN 105.747154 education_expenditure_gdp_share measles_immunisation_rate \ 0 NaN 56.0 1 2.729770 86.0 2 4.749247 79.0 health_expenditure_gdp_share income_inequality unemployment_rate \ 0 23.088169 NaN 14.100 1 6.193681 NaN 10.137 2 3.623043 NaN 12.346 life_expectancy total_population 0 65.617 40578842.0 1 78.769 2777689.0 2 76.129 45477389.0 ``` ::: ::: This report explores selected 2022 World Development Indicators: - GDP per capita (USD) - Life expectancy (years) - Inflation rate (%) These represent key economic, demographic, and financial dimensions across countries. ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd df = pd.read_csv("wdi.csv") df = df[["country", "gdp_per_capita", "life_expectancy", "inflation_rate"]].dropna() df.head(3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}

Inflation averages 12.7% and is highly dispersed. ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} n_countries = df["country"].nunique() n_countries ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` 174 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} corr = df[["gdp_per_capita", "life_expectancy", "inflation_rate"]].corr() corr ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}

Visualizations Figure: Life expectancy vs GDP per capita ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} import matplotlib.pyplot as plt #| label: fig-scatter #| fig-cap: "Life expectancy vs GDP per capita (2022) [@worldbankWDI]." #| echo: false import matplotlib.pyplot as plt plt.figure() plt.scatter(df["gdp_per_capita"], df["life_expectancy"], alpha=0.7) plt.xlabel("GDP per capita (USD)") plt.ylabel("Life expectancy (years)") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` Text(0, 0.5, 'Life expectancy (years)') ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](05_report_files/figure-pdf/cell-8-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: Figure: Inflation rate distribution across countries ::: {#fig-hist .cell execution_count=8} ::: {#fig-hist-1 .cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` Text(0, 0.5, 'Number of countries') ``` Distribution of inflation rates (2022) [@worldbankWDI]. ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](05_report_files/figure-pdf/fig-hist-output-2.pdf){#fig-hist-2} ::: ::: Figure: Top 10 GDP per capita countries ::: {#fig-bar .cell execution_count=9} ::: {#fig-bar-1 .cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ``` Text(0.5, 0, 'GDP per capita (USD)') ``` Top 10 countries by GDP per capita (2022)[@worldbankWDI]. ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](05_report_files/figure-pdf/fig-bar-output-2.pdf){#fig-bar-2} ::: ::: As shown in Figure @fig-scatter, higher GDP per capita generally aligns with longer life expectancy. The spread of inflation across countries in Figure @fig-hist, together with the skewed top incomes in Figure @fig-bar, explains why dispersion in Table @tbl-summary is large. Indicators come from the World Development Indicators accessed via wbgapi [@wdi; @wbgapi]. Analysis uses pandas and matplotlib [@mckinney2010; @hunter2007]. ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Export dataset for slides to reuse df.to_csv("world_indicators_2022.csv", index=False) ``` :::
